Defective Products; Warranty; Support
***.
During the Term Supplier may extend an offer to Reseller for a Returns Discount Program, whereby the Supplier will
rebate a percentage of the cost of goods sold in lieu of accepting End-User returns. In the event no Returns Discount
Program has been entered into by the Parties, Supplier will not accept Returned Product, except for cases of Defective
Products.
perturbation.changed_text:
Defective Products; Warranty; Support
***.
During the Term Supplier may extend an offer to Reseller for a Returns Discount Program, whereby the Supplier will
rebate a percentage of the cost of goods sold in lieu of accepting End-User returns. In the event no Returns Discount
Program has been entered into by the Parties, Supplier will not accept Returned Product.
perturbation.explanation: By removing "except for cases of Defective Products," the contract now implies that no returns are accepted, even for defective products. This contradicts consumer protection laws in many US states (and potentially other countries in the Territory), which mandate that consumers have the right to return or receive compensation for defective goods. This introduces legal risk because the contract is now less compliant with standard consumer protection legislation.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Breach of Implied Warranty of Merchantability under the Uniform Commercial Code (UCC), Magnuson-Moss Warranty Act (if applicable).

perturbation.changed_text:
Disclaimer of Warranties. UNLESS SPECIFIED OTHERWISE HEREIN (INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO
THE BACK TO BACK WARRANTY SPECIFIED IN SECTION 6.5) AND WITHOUT LIMITATION TO ANY
WARRANTY WHICH SUPPLIER MAY, IN ITS SOLE DISCRETION, MAKE TO ANY CUSTOMER AND/OR

perturbation.explanation: By removing the phrase ", MERCHANTABILITY AND FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE.", the contract attempts to disclaim the implied warranties of merchantability and fitness for a particular purpose. While disclaimers are possible, they must be conspicuous and often use specific language. In many US jurisdictions (governed by UCC), attempting to disclaim these warranties entirely or not doing so conspicuously can be challenged. This increases legal risk as it undermines consumer rights.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Uniform Commercial Code (UCC) Article 2 - Sales, specifically provisions related to implied warranties of merchantability and fitness for a particular purpose.

perturbation.original_text:
In addition to the foregoing, if, at the time of termination of this Agreement, Reseller
shall have additional Product units in its inventory and is able to sell them to Customers and/or End Users (including,
without limitation, any Product units for which Reseller has or is obligated to pay the Supplier the purchase price
therefor but which have not yet been delivered to the Reseller by Supplier, which Supplier hereby agrees to either
deliver as otherwise contemplated by this Agreement as if it had not terminated or to refund the purchase price
therefor), then the licenses and appointments described in Section 2 shall remain in effect with respect to such unsold
Product units (and such Section 2 shall not terminate) until the earlier of (i) the date on which the last Product in
Reseller’s inventory is sold to a Customer and/or End User, or (ii) 1 year from the date of the termination of this
Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text:
In addition to the foregoing, if, at the time of termination of this Agreement, Reseller
shall have additional Product units in its inventory and is able to sell them to Customers and/or End Users then the licenses and appointments described in Section 2 shall remain in effect with respect to such unsold
Product units (and such Section 2 shall not terminate) until the earlier of (i) the date on which the last Product in

perturbation.explanation: By omitting the clause "(including, without limitation, any Product units for which Reseller has or is obligated to pay the Supplier the purchase price therefor but which have not yet been delivered to the Reseller by Supplier, which Supplier hereby agrees to either deliver as otherwise contemplated by this Agreement as if it had not terminated or to refund the purchase price therefor)", the supplier is no longer obligated to deliver or refund the purchase price for products that the reseller has already paid for but has not received at the time of the agreement's termination. This introduces a legal risk as it potentially allows the supplier to retain funds for goods not delivered, which could be construed as unjust enrichment or a breach of contract based on principles of good faith and fair dealing implied in contract law.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing, principles of unjust enrichment, and basic contract law regarding payment for goods not received.
